folder: Prospect Park & Surveyors Camp., Brooklyn, NY
text:
Prospect Park:

A surveyors camp situated in the Park while the Park was being laid out and landscaped.

About 1885.

Beal Photographer.
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park - Surveyors Camp.

text:
Monuments can be to others than statesmen and warriors. In Prospect Park's "Flower Garden" are several erected to the composers of music; this one to :

MOZART
Presented to the City of Brooklyn
by the
United German Singers
of the city
First Prize at the 18th
National Saengerfest
Held at Philadelphia
June 23rd
1897
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park.

text:
Prospect Park Entrance, at Grand Army Plaza, showing the monument in honor of the Civil War dead.

Early 1900's

Gift of Urbrook Collection

circa. 1900

text:
Prospect Park, Brooklyn, showing two views of the interior of the park in 1905.  Note the turn-out on an early Spring day and how radically both the attire of the men and women have changed in the last thirty-five years.

Views 1, 2: 1905

Gift of Samuel Landsman
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park.

folder: Prospect Park (Abraham Lincoln statue)., Brooklyn, NY
text:
Prospect park: a view of a monument to Abraham Lincoln, who was President of the United States during the Civil War.  It is located south of Breeze Hill.
About 1906.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park (Abraham Lincoln statue).

folder: Prospect Park & East Drive., Brooklyn, NY
text:
(1)
Prospect Park; East Drive, a view of one of the delightful drives in the Park. This view shows to the right, a marker establishing Battle Pass, upon which was erected the first line of defense in the battle of Long Island, during the Revolutionary War.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2) and (3)
Views 2 and 3 show interior views of the Park.

George Balgue.
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park - East Drive.

folder: Prospect Park & Fair Ground Inc., Brooklyn, NY
text:
(1)
Prospect Park Fair Grounds Inc., bounded on the north by King's Highway, on the west by Mc Donald Ave., on the south by Neck Road, on the east by Coney Island Ave., was composed of 60 acres purchased by Geo. Powers and J. Payton, who established a one mile trotting course. These grounds were sold to a group of prominent Brooklyn residents, who formed the Brooklyn Jockey Club, which enlarged this tract to 460 acres at a cost of $400,000. It was opened in 1887. This view shows a straightaway and "Grand Stand" - To-day (1929) Stryker Street runs through the front of and along the site of the stand. The new tract was bounded on the north by Ave. Q, on the east by Ocean Parkway, on the west by Mc Donald Ave., and East 2nd Street, and on the south by Ave. V and Johnson Lane. The Dwyer brothers and the prominent Brooklynites incorporated under the name of the Brooklyn Jockey Club Track of Gravesend, Inc. The last meet was held in 1910. In 1922, the grounds were sold for $750,000 to William E. Harriman, and this section became known as the King's Club district.
?
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, after the demolition of track buildings.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park - Fair Ground Inc.

text:
Prospect Park, plaza:
A general view north from the Knights of Columbus Building at the west side of Prospect Park West and between President and Union Streets.  Shown at the right is the southern part of the Plaza, the entrance to Prospect Park.  In the foreground (left) is seen 929-949 Union Street.  All or part of these buildings in this view, facing on the Plaza between Union Street and Flatbush Ave. (seen in center of the view), have been replaced by modern apartment houses.

June 1926.

Brown Brothers.
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park Plaza.

text:
Prospect Park,Plaza: A general view east from the Knights of Columbus Building located at the N.W. corner of President Street and Prospect Park West, showing in the foreground the Memorial Arch.  In the center of the view, east from Flatbush Ave., (trolley car thereon) is Eastern Parkway.  The buildings on the south side of the Parkway are the Mt. Prospect Reservoir, and the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences; on the north side in their order are the Union Temple of Brooklyn, the Copley Plaza Apartments (under construction), the Abraham Lincoln, etc.

June 1926.

Brown Brothers.
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park Plaza

folder: Prospect Park Arch & entrance., Brooklyn, NY
text:
The entrance to Prospect Park. The buildings from left to right are located at Eastern Parkway and Union Street.  The roads encircling the arch from left to right, are East and West Plaza Streets. This arch is dedicated to the Soldiers and Sailors of the Civil War.
About 1928.
Ewing Galloway.
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park Arch - entrance.

text:
Prospect Park
Leffert's Homestead

C. Manley De Bevoise
51-05 Browvale Lane
Little Neck, N.Y.

Net - A-589
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park.

folder: Prospect Park & Leffert's Homestead., Brooklyn, NY
text:
LEFFERTS HOMESTEAD   Prospect Park, Brooklyn.  This late Dutch Colonial house was rebuilt in 1777 by Lieutenant Peter Lefferts after partial destruction by fire during the Battle of Long Island.  Although the low gambrel roof of the building is typical of the style, the beautiful detail of the main entrance is unusual.  In 1913 the house was presented to the city by descendants of the original owner.

Bank of New York Calendar 1967-68
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park - Leffert's Homestead.

title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park - Grecian shelter.

text:
Tollgate, Flatbush

When Flatbush Ave. was a dirt road, privately owned, this was the toll house.  Preserved it still stands at the Southwesterly entrance to Prospect Park, Brooklyn.  The men standing in the Toll House is the late Eugene Armbruster, one of the most noted historians.

0.4
H-4
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park.

text:
In Prospect Park, Brooklyn, a memorial to a Battalian of Maryland soldiers which was almost completely wiped out in a rear action covering the retreat of the American Army in the Battle of Long Island on August 27th, 1776.

A

Full of marshed section

315G
LOCAL HISTORY
AND GENEALOGY
title: Brooklyn: Prospect Park.
